The majority of studies describing underlying mechanisms for successful invasion have focused on above- rather than belowground processes, however accumulating evidence suggests soil organisms may be important regulators of plant invasions
37– 40 . Although many invasive plants are mycotrophic (~ 82%
41 , and fungal associations have been shown to both facilitate and hinder invasion success
42– 50 , the role of AM mycelial networks in the invasion process has not been determined. Further, information on the role of mycorrhizae on invasive plant success is available for only a small number of plant species at this time.
